You should be able to increase your range by shifting into 4th any time you can. The volt consumption is basically based on how many revolutions the motor makes... same as when it was a gas engine... the higher your RPMs the higher your gas mileage. Thus, if you were in 4th at all times the RPMs of the electric motor would be lower and therefore you would get more miles per volt. I‚Äôd try 3rd off the line, then into 4th as soon as you are in the 20mph zone.

The way to make your batteries last longer is to not charge them up to full each time you charge them. The lower your top them to, the longer they will last. If you stop at 75% most of the time and only go over that when you really need the full range, they'll last a long, long time.
100% true.  If you can run it 75% -> 25%, technically, that's optimal I think for longevity.
the same is true for discharge, don't go to 0, they will last even longer

Hey Louis you do not have to do much to run SVO or straight vegi oil in any diesel. On your bus, change out fuel lines with ones that can handle vegi oil since original ones will melt and go bad quickly. Second, add another fuel holding tank for the vegi oil because you need to heat up the vegi oil before it gets pumped to engine, You always start the bus with regular diesel and then you switch over to SVO system and run from there. You will need to change out fuel filter more often the first few times you run on SVO as it cleans out the lines and fuel system. Good look!

Having had one of those VW campers, I would say that 60 mph is unsafe under any condition. Just from your video, the suspension sounds as rickety as they always were. They are very hard to control at high speed and the original brakes are barely enough to stop it. Before you go pushing the limits, make sure you have a way to closely monitor your battery temperature and a way to quickly disconnect it if it overheats as well as an impact detecting disconnect in case you are in an accident. Of course, if you hit anything head on, you're as good as gone anyway. There's very little front protection. You would be wise to put an upgraded brake system with larger calipers and disks on it.

@AMLagonda You ever driven one? I did for a while and took some trips with it and it was not fun driving on the highway or even up a steep grade. It blew out a couple of engines which is common for the VW campers. They put metal towing loops on the front for a reason.
Mate they can cruise all day at that speed even with a 2 litre petrol engine.

Flying back regularly completely negates the environmental benifits of converting the van to an EV (and then some), I'd recommend looking at alternative transport methods. I'm not sure what the transport links are like in Costa Rica so unfortunately I can't recommend anything in particular. If you're set on flying, maybe try and contact the HyFlyer project based out of Orkney, it could provide a solution in the coming years based on their recent successes and I'm sure any exposure would help their progress!

@Seb Hudson true but it‚Äôs better than not doing anything and simply flying, people are coming for him because of what he said but he‚Äôs obviously gonna try to fly as less as possible if he can and even when he does he‚Äôll try to be as green as possible

@Ryukachoo Unfortunately, whilst the carbon offset schemes are a good start, we can't rely on them. There are a few studies which show that a forest the size of Brazil would be required to meet the 1.5C target which isn't attainable in a reasonable timeframe, if at all. This is alongside a massive reduction in carbon-based fuels. Behaviours and habits need to be altered first and once we limit CO2e output, we can then look into direct air capture using tree planting schemes and technologies such as those being developed by Carbon Engineering.
On a more personal note, I'm not a huge fan of these tree planting schemes as they allow the (usually) wealthy to pay a bit extra to travel 'guilt free' using a highly polluting method, rather than encouraging them to change their travelling habits.
